title: aramco oil ipo saudi arabia stock market listing shelved riyadh denies reports
story: Created with Sketch.Sources said deal had been called off, however Saudi denials will come as a relief to advisers who stand to make $200m out of the IPOClick to followThe IndependentThe listing of Aramco would raise up to $100bn for Saudi ArabiaRiyadh has moved to quash reports the flotation of state owned oil giant Saudi Aramco has been called off. The IPO of a 5 per cent chunk of the company would be the biggest stock market float on record, with an estimated value of $2 trillion (£1.6 trillion), and would be expected to raise up to $100bn for Saudi Arabia. The move has been in the works for several years&nbspbut no date or location has been set&nbspand, on Wednesday, Reuters reported the flotation had been shelved. The news service said Saudi Arabia had pulled the domestic and international listings of Aramco and cited senior industry sources. It also reported advisers working on the deal had been disbanded. The news followed reports this year the chances of the kingdom continuing with plans for an international listing were “diminishing”. However on Thursday, Saudi Arabia’s energy minister&nbspKhalid al-Falih said: “The government remains committed to the initial public offering of Saudi Aramco, in accordance with the appropriate circumstances and appropriate time chosen by the government.”The Saudi government also said, in preparation for the listing, it had “undertaken a number of major preparatory measures, including issuing a new income tax law as it relates to hydrocarbons activities reissuing a long term exclusive concession and appointing a new board of directors, amongst other measures to safeguard its interests and those of the company’s future private shareholders”.Chance of Aramco listing in London or New York ‘may be diminishing’Public listing of Saudi oil company may be delayed until 2019UK Government agrees $2bn loan guarantee for Saudi AramcoLondon, New York and Hong Kong are among potential hosts for the record breaking IPO. The kingdom’s denial of the IPO cancellation will come as a relief to bankers and advisers who stand to make $200m from the float. According to reports, international banks JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley and HSBC were appointed as global coordinators and boutique investment banks Moelis &amp Co and Evercore were chosen as independent advisors. title: brexit no deal more likely than not kpmg survey reveals
story: Created with Sketch.Click to followThe IndependentSeven in 10 people questioned said they think prices will riseBrexit: Every demographic in UK now thinks no deal more likely than not, survey revealsAll sections of UK society now think that it is more likely than not the country will crash out of the EU without a trade deal, a new survey has revealed.Every demographic, employment status and political group believes a no-deal Brexit is the likely outcome as negotiations continue to stall, KPMG found.In the poll of more than 3,000 people, 54 per cent said no deal was likely compared to just 20 per cent who thought it was unlikely.The findings come as The Independent’s #FinalSay campaign, which is seeking to ensure the people have the chance to vote on the Brexit deal, surpassed 700,000 signatures.The Independent and the People’s Vote campaign have also joined forces for a mass march through central London later this year.Seven in 10 people questioned by KPMG said they think prices will rise in the event of no deal and 69 per cent said they will change their consumer behaviour.Women and those aged under 35 were more likely than others to say they would have to change by taking action such as stockpiling certain good or cutting essential spending.&nbspOverall, 45 per cent of respondents said leaving without a trade deal will be bad for the country, while just 25 per cent said they think it will be good.“This survey shows the public expect a ‘no deal’ Brexit and plan to spend accordingly. The results reveal how people are anticipating substantial disruption in the short to medium-term, before they expect Brexit to have a more positive effect on the economy in the medium to long term.&nbsp“During this period of disruption Brits expect prices to go up, delays at airports and sea ports, plus a potential hit to the pound.&nbsp The mood music of the Brexit talks is likely to have a direct effect on consumer confidence.”Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: us china trade talks ftse 100 no deal brexit global markets
story: Created with Sketch.'The bar had been set low for the trade negotiations and it appears that even those low expectations have been missed,' one analyst saidClick to followThe IndependentThe US and China issued fresh tariffs during trade negotiations this weekGlobal markets weighed down as US-China trade talks fail to yield resultsEuropean markets got off to a slow start on Friday, after trade talks between the US and China failed to offer up any solution to the brewing tensions between the two economic giants. The FTSE dipped in early trading, while Asian markets also nudged down overnight, after negotiations concluded with no results. Mid-level officials from both countries met in Washington this week to discuss trade, but fresh tariffs were applied by both the US and China on Thursday, which “highlighted the lack of progress being made by the two nations”, London Capital Group’s Jasper Lawler said.“The bar had been set low for the trade negotiations and it appears that even those low expectations have been missed,” he added. Earlier in the week, &nbspPresident Trump had said he did not “anticipate much” from the talks. On Thursday, White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said: “We concluded two days of discussions with counterparts from China and exchanged views on how to achieve fairness, balance, and reciprocity in the economic relationship.”Meanwhile, the publication of the first round of the government’s ‘technical notices’ in preparation for a potential no deal Brexit was poorly received, pulling the FTSE 100 down to close lower on Thursday, and knocking 0.6 per cent off the pound against the dollar. Trump sends dollar tumbling with swipe at central bank and China talksBrexit is bad for steelworkers – so our union backs a Final SayHere's why we need to strengthen global cooperation on tradeConnor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said the muted market reaction on Friday offered some reason to be optimistic. “Given the amount of bad news out there at the moment - from Thursday’s trade talk-undermining tariff tit-for-tatting between the US and China, the ominous clouds of a no deal Brexit, and Trump’s potential legal problems - the markets have done well to not lose their heads this week,” he said.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: bingley music live music at myrtle festival bradford success urban
story: Created with Sketch.Bradford Council never set out to make a full-blown music festival, but this&nbspevent is now one of the calender highlights of the year with a lineup to rival nearby LeedsClick to followThe IndependentIt started 27 years ago and now welcomes more than 15,000 people over the last weekend in AugustAt the end of summer in 1991, Bradford Council decided to stage a free music event in Myrtle Park in Bingley. It was a fairly low-key event, with a portable stage not much bigger than the park’s bandstand. The lineup was comprised of mainly tribute acts.Fast forward to 2018, and Bingley Music Live, as the event evolved into, is preparing for its biggest three-day festival yet, on the weekend of Friday 31 August. This time the roster is a little more impressive: Noel Gallagher’s High Flying Birds, Jake Bugg, Public Image Ltd, Shed Seven, former Spice Girl Melanie C… and all on a stage that wouldn’t be out of place at one of the summer’s big-name festivals.But, so what? Festivals are big business in the UK, and the summer calendar is stuffed with internationally-renowned acts zipping between fields across the country. Just down the road from Bradford, the Leeds Festival is twinned with its more venerable cousin Reading, and together they form the apex of the festival pyramid with old-stager Glastonbury (when it’s not having a fallow year, like this summer).But also on the calendar is Latitude, the Isle of Wight Festival, RiZE (formerly the V Festival), Wireless, Creamfields, BBC Music’s Big Weekend, Bestival… it seems that no matter where you are in the country, sling a 12in picture disc like a frisbee any time over the summer and you’re almost certain to hit a music superstar on the head.But what makes Bingley Music Live a slightly different beast is that just like the inaugural Music at Myrtle&nbspevent in 1991, it is still run by the local authority. No longer free, of course, because you don’t get Noel Gallagher out of bed on the sort of money you can make up by adding a few quid on the council tax bills. But value for money certainly, compared to the big commercial festivals, and certainly pulling its weight in the ring with many of them.A spokesperson for Bradford Council said&nbspthat when Music at Myrtle was set up in 1991, nobody really expected that it would become the major player it is now. She says:&nbsp“When we held our first small free concert few could have envisaged that the festival would grow to attract such big names as Pet Shop Boys, Kaiser Chiefs, Manic Street Preachers, Chic and Nile Rogers, All Saints, Jess Glynne&nbspand James who have all played over recent years.”The key, though, is that Bingley Music Live has grown organically. Bradford Council never set out to make a full-blown festival, it expanded a little bit year by year. She adds:&nbsp“Although it has come a long way from its humble beginnings and it is unusual for a council to be involved in such a big festival we have grown it gradually and now it sees 15,000 people a day flock to the town for festival weekend.”&nbspIn its early years, Music at Myrtle was split into themed days, with old rockers such as Bradford’s own Smokie on the bill, newer bands for the younger audience, and jazz. In 1998 Bradford Council partnered with local radio station Pulse to make the event a two-day festival, with Pulse using their clout and contacts book to bring in bigger names such as Liberty X, McFly, Rachel Stevens and another Bradford boy-done-good, Gareth Gates.That continued into the 2000s, until what was then billed as the Party in the Park hit its first major bump in the road. In February 2007, the event was summarily cancelled. Rising costs and declining audiences were blamed, and the Pulse’s station director, Tony Wilkinson, told the local paper,&nbsp and&nbspArgus, that support from the music industry for such small festivals was on the wane. He said that the record labels did not have “as many artists out on promotional tours to provide a top class running order”.Despite its small size, the festival has attracted larger, mainstream acts such as Maximo ParkWhat nobody envisaged in 2007, though, was that the music industry was in the throes of a massive shakeup. Downloading and streaming of music was in its infancy then, and music acts still made the majority of their money from physical album and single sales. However, a decade on, that situation is reversed nowadays it’s the touring of live shows and pounding the festival beat that earns pop and rock bands a crust.It would be nice to think that Bradford Council was playing something of a blinder back in 2007, but the chances are that it was pure serendipity. Either way, within a couple of months of the announcement that the Myrtle Park festival was dead, it rose from the ashes.The original plan was to scale back on the A-listers and give more of a platform to unknown, local bands. The rescue package had been put together wholly by Bradford Council, and they were obviously mindful of the budgetary restrictions of putting on a big festival but still wanting to provide residents with a music event of some description.Indeed, it was the residents of Bingley in particular who lobbied the council to save the festival in some form. This was at a time when the financial crisis was just bubbling over, and it’s fair to say that Bradford had been hit harder than most cities. Neighbouring Leeds had stolen a march on city centre development and by the mid-2000s had a thriving retail and leisure sector that put it in a stronger position to weather the credit crunch.aren’t too far removed from its neighbouring Leeds&nbspBefore the financial collapse, Bradford had been on the up as well. Large swathes of the city centre had been demolished to make way for a brand new shopping centre built by Westfield. The majority of the work on taking down the tired, old buildings began in 2004, but by 2007 everything had stalled, leaving Bradford with an infamous hole in the ground that made it look as though it was ground zero of a meteor strike. It wasn’t until 2015 that the centre was completed and opened… and, to be fair, did help to kickstart a much-needed revitalisation of Bradford.So it was understandable in that atmosphere in 2007 that people wanted some form of entertainment, and Bingley Music Live was it. That year’s festival was indeed&nbsppared down, but still attracted some recognisable names – Bruce Foxton’s post-Paul Weller “From The Jam” outfit, the Charlatans, the Bluetones. The following year brought the Happy Mondays, Echo and the Bunnymen, and local heroes Terrorvision.&nbspBy the time the first headliners the Charlatans returned in 2012, the festival had added a third day on the Friday, and the festival was really on an upward curve.But can a local authority really justify the cost? There are partners of course, including Ticketline, Mercure Hotels and Carlsberg. But surely it doesn’t make any money?According to a Bradford Council reply to a freedom of information request last month asking for income and expenditure on Bingley Music Live over the past three years, in 2015 there was income of £946,000 against just over £1m in costs. In 2016 income was down at £822,000 against very similar costs, but last year, with costs standing at £1.15m, there was gross income of £1.3m… leaving a net surplus of £222,000.Having attended the event last year, those figure’s aren’t surprising. It was packed and money was flowing over the bars and food concessions. It’s also a very family-oriented event. And with ticket sales ensuring 15,000 come through the gates every day this year –&nbspwhich the coup of booking Noel Gallagher has certainly helped with –&nbspit looks likely that Bingley Music Live is on an upward trend.Being in the middle of one of the Bradford district’s big towns as well, rather than in splendid isolation on a field somewhere in Hampshire, there are extra benefits. My council spokesperson says: “The event is a big thing for Bingley’s businesses, with its many excellent pubs, bars, shops and places to eat all busy with people for the full weekend. The festival is also embraced by the local Bradford and Bingley Sports Club who provide camping for festivalgoers on their fields.”Ariana Grande and James Corden perform hit-filled version of TitanicWhy drag queen Vicky Vox is starring in Little Shop of HorrorsCamp Bestival forced to close early due to poor weather conditionsWhile Bingley Music Live might be unusual in being local authority-run, its model of being an “urban festival” is one that is becoming increasingly popular… and can pay idends for local economies.Journalist Claude Lynch, writing in CityMetric earlier this year, said that while the big, camp-out-all-weekend festivals were declining, smaller, urban festivals were thriving… and possibly because of a sense of community. He wrote: “Multiple studies into the dynamics and economics of festivals make similar arguments about how to drive ‘re-patronising’ – in other words, how to make festivalgoers want to come back next year. Evidence suggests that ‘social identification’ – having something in common with other festivalgoers – is often just as important as the quality of the music or the food. Festivals can capitalise on this boon of social identification by offering a self-contained event designed&nbspwith both locals and tourists in mind. Locals are more likely to patronise events that emphasise community spirit while tourists are enthused by events that symbolise and epitomise the local culture.”From very humble beginnings 27 years ago, Bingley Music Live has survived and thrived, often against the odds, and when international superstar Noel Gallagher takes the stage in a couple of weeks’ time, it will be the culmination of the dogged determination that gets things done in this part of the world… and looks like providing the template for the future of live music.For more information go to bingleymusicliveMusic at MyrtleEnter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?Despite its small size, the festival has attracted larger, mainstream acts such as Maximo Park

Brexiteers accused Philip Hammond&nbsp of launching another “dodgy Project Fear” with warnings over the economic impact of a no-deal Brexit.In a&nbspletter published on Thursday, the chancellor reiterated estimates in a government analysis that borrowing could be £80bn higher if the UK crashes out of the bloc and GDP could fall by 10 per cent.But his remarks came just hours after his cabinet colleague and Brexit secretary, Dominic Raab, attempted to reassure the public over a disorderly exit and cited “opportunities” that could arise.Labour not taking new Brexit deal vote off the table, McDonnell saysConservatives reject Banks' attempt to join partyUK expats face losing access to pensions in event of no-deal BrexitLabour says new Brexit referendum is possible if May's deal rejectedDismissing the chancellor’s warning on BBC Newsnight, the Eurosceptic Tory MP Jacob Rees-Mogg said: “I think a free trade deal can be achieved, but that leaving on WTO terms is not as absurdly frightening as the Chancellor of the Exchequer thinks it may be.“The Treasury's Brexit panic means you can no longer trust the Treasury's forecasts.”Marcus Fysh, a second Tory MP, referred to the Treasury’s previous “dubious” forecasts before adding that the chancellor seemed determined to wheel them out again for yet another instalment of dodgy project fear.A government source also told the Daily : “This was a deliberate intervention by Philip, he knew exactly what he was doing.”Pro-EU campaigners described the contents of the letter as a “Brexit bazooka” while John McDonnell, the shadow chancellor, said Mr Hammond ad threw a “hand grenade” into the debate over a no-deal scenario.But the Cabinet Office minister, David Lidington, defended the chancellor, claiming the letter published on Thursday said “nothing new” and that Mr Hammond was “absolutely committed” to the prime minister’s Chequers blueprint for Brexit.This is provisional analysis that the Treasury published back in January this year and I think all Philip was doing was simply referring back to that in response to a senior member of Parliament,” Mr Lidington told BBC Radio 4’s Today programme.In his letter, addressed to the senior Tory MP and chair of the Treasury Select Committee, Nicky Morgan, Mr Hammond said: This January provisional analysis estimated that in a no-dealWTO scenario, GDP would be 7.7 title: us china trade talks ftse 100 no deal brexit global markets
story: Created with Sketch.'The bar had been set low for the trade negotiations and it appears that even those low expectations have been missed,' one analyst saidClick to followThe IndependentThe US and China issued fresh tariffs during trade negotiations this weekGlobal markets weighed down as US-China trade talks fail to yield resultsEuropean markets got off to a slow start on Friday, after trade talks between the US and China failed to offer up any solution to the brewing tensions between the two economic giants. The FTSE dipped in early trading, while Asian markets also nudged down overnight, after negotiations concluded with no results. Mid-level officials from both countries met in Washington this week to discuss trade, but fresh tariffs were applied by both the US and China on Thursday, which “highlighted the lack of progress being made by the two nations”, London Capital Group’s Jasper Lawler said.“The bar had been set low for the trade negotiations and it appears that even those low expectations have been missed,” he added. Earlier in the week, &nbspPresident Trump had said he did not “anticipate much” from the talks. On Thursday, White House spokeswoman Lindsay Walters said: “We concluded two days of discussions with counterparts from China and exchanged views on how to achieve fairness, balance, and reciprocity in the economic relationship.”Meanwhile, the publication of the first round of the government’s ‘technical notices’ in preparation for a potential no deal Brexit was poorly received, pulling the FTSE 100 down to close lower on Thursday, and knocking 0.6 per cent off the pound against the dollar. Trump sends dollar tumbling with swipe at central bank and China talksBrexit is bad for steelworkers – so our union backs a Final SayHere's why we need to strengthen global cooperation on tradeConnor Campbell, financial analyst at Spreadex, said the muted market reaction on Friday offered some reason to be optimistic. “Given the amount of bad news out there at the moment - from Thursday’s trade talk-undermining tariff tit-for-tatting between the US and China, the ominous clouds of a no deal Brexit, and Trump’s potential legal problems - the markets have done well to not lose their heads this week,” he said.Enter your email addressFill out this fieldregister with your social account or click here to log inAre you sure you want to submit this vote?Are you sure you want to mark this comment as inappropriate?Are you sure you want to delete this comment?

title: brexit news no deal brexit dominic raab technical papers theresa may
story: While he said a good Brexit deal between the UK and EU remains &ldquoin our sights, Mr Raab today outlined the &ldquopractical and proportionate preparations for a no-deal exit.&nbspHe played down Project Fear warnings of stockpiling food, joking at a major speech this morning: &ldquoLet me assure you that, contrary to one of the wilder claims, you will still be able to enjoy a BLT after Brexit, and there are no plans to deploy the army to maintain food supplies.And his Department for Exiting the European Union released 24 technical papers outlining how the Government was preparing for a no-deal Brexit, from trade and finances to cigarettes and organic food.&nbspSee below for an 11-part breakdown of how the Government is preparing for a no-deal Brexit.&nbsp                Second Brexit referendum would trigger 'civil DISOBEDIENCE'                 Brexit WARNING: UK would 'fall apart' in event of no-deal with EUBANKING, INSURANCE AND FINANCIAL SERVICESExtra charges for credit and debit card users could be one of the main effects felt by ordinary households in the event of a no deal Brexit, the Government's technical documents say.&nbspBriton visiting EU countries could find their charges have increased as a result the sudden change in regulation of financial services.UK citizens living in Europe face the possibility of losing access to their pension income and other financial services, according to technical papers on no-deal Brexit preparations.&nbspBritain will be ready for Brexit, even in a no-deal scenario (Image: getty)Households could face extra debit and credit card charges (Image: getty)Lending and deposit services, insurance and annuities - which people rely on for a regular pension income - are among the financial products which expats could struggle to get access to, it was suggested.TRADE &amp TARIFFSBusinesses exporting to EU countries are being advised to prepare for possible major changes in customs procedures in the event of no deal, according to the Whitehall papers.&nbspThere would be immediate changes to the procedures that apply to businesses trading with the EU. It would mean the free circulation of goods between the UK and EU would cease, says one technical note.&nbsp                Brexit: How holidays will not be affected for Britons                Second Brexit referendum would trigger 'civil DISOBEDIENCE' Customs procedures look set to change with a no-deal (Image: getty)Businesses have been advised to start making preparations for a no-deal Brexit by acquiring logistics software and consulting customs brokers to assist with any new trading regulations.Firms that export and import from the EU may also have to apply for licences to continue to do so. Consumers could also see the cost of their online shopping increase in the event of a no-deal Brexit.TOBACCO AND E-CIGARETTESImages of lung damage and dead bodies on cigarette packs would have to be changed under a no-deal Brexit. Copyright for the current images is owned by the European Commission so the UK could no longer legally use them and new images would need to be created.A no-deal Brexit would also mean new systems to register tobacco and e-cigarette products, according to a technical paper on labelling tobacco products.One of the Whitehall technical notes says: If there's no deal we would introduce new picture warnings for tobacco products as the copyright for the existing picture library is owned by the European Commission.Manufacturers will need to ensure that tobacco products which include picture warnings produced from Exit Day onwards will be labelled with new picture warnings.&nbspNUCLEAR SAFETYParliament has already passed legislation to ensure safety in the management of nuclear material in the UK after Brexit. In the event of no deal, the regime overseen by the Office for Nuclear Regulation will immediately come into force.&nbspThe UK would immediately leave the Euratom, the European atomic agency, in the event of a no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe Government has pledged to continue to provide funding to the nuclear promised by the EU under research and develop programmes.&nbspFOREIGN AIDThe Government will promise to continue funding EU aid programmes even in the event of a no-deal Brexit to avoid existing assistance being cut short or terminated, say the Whitehall documents.&nbspNeither of these outcomes would be acceptable to the UK Government, says one technical note.FARMINGThe Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs will guarantee to fund outstanding cash due farmers and landowners from the EU's rural development programmes, the Whitehall documents say.The funding will remain at existing levels until the end of this parliament, expected in 2022, for the whole of the UK, a technical notice on payments reiterates.&nbspMEDICINESNew medicines will need approval from UK authorities before they can be made available to patients in the event of a no-deal Brexit.&nbspThe Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), which regulates drugs in the UK, will take on the functions of the EU if an agreement is not reached by March 29.&nbspUK authorities will need to approve new medicines (Image: getty)Products will have to go through national assessment before they receive market authorisation to be sold in the UK, according to a technical paper on no-deal Brexit preparations.One of the technical documents says: After EU exit, to market a product in the UK, an initial market authorisation application will need to be submitted to the MHRA and will go through a national assessment.MHRA will take a streamlined approach to approving UK market authorisation applications that places no greater burden on industry and ensures that patients can access new and innovative medicines at the same time as EU patients.ORGANIC FOODOrganic food labelling will have to be changed with the EU organic label in the shape of a green leaf of stars stripped off.&nbspOrganic food businesses could only be allowed to export to the EU if they were certified by an organic certification body approved by the European Commission.&nbspWORKPLACE RIGHTSMinisters insist workers&rsquo rights including working time regulations would be unaffected, according to the Whitehall papers.Workers in the UK will continue to be entitled to the rights they have under UK law, covering those aspects which come from UK law, says one of the technical notes.&nbspIt adds: Domestic legislation already exceeds EU-required levels of employment protections in a number of ways.&nbspSTATE AIDMinisters will create a new framework to ensure that rules preventing unfair subsidies to business and other bodes in the event of no deal, say the Whitehall papers.&nbspThe Competition and Markets Authority, which is a world-leading competition authority, will take on the role of enforcement and supervision for the whole of the UK, according to one of the technical notes.The UK strongly supports a rigorous state aid system - this is good for taxpayers, consumers and for businesses.STUDENTSFunding for a major student exchange programme will be guaranteed until 2020 even if talks collapse, the Whitehall documents said yesterday.&nbspThe Government will provide cash for the Erasmus scheme, according to one technical note. The Government commits to underwrite funding for the entire lifetime of projects agreed before Brexit, the note says.

Exit talks will &lsquoSLIP&rsquo past OctoberDominic Raab made a speech about the government's plans in the case of a no-deal Brexit today (Image: )This is because any direct financial savings are outweighed by the indirect fiscal consequences of a smaller economy.The initial, January cross-Whitehall analysis is now undergoing a process of refinement in the run-up to a parliamentary vote on the deal.However, we expect the analysis to show that for scenarios in which we have higher barriers to trade with the EU there will be a more damaging effect on the economy and public finances.On the Government's preferred approach, Mr Hammond went on: It is expected that the economic and fiscal impacts of the white paper model will be substantially better than no deal, protecting jobs and livelihoods and supporting both the UK and EU's commitments to no hard border between Northern Ireland and Ireland.Mrs Morgan seized on the Chancellor's remarks as confirmation of an allegedly disastrous impact on the economy.She said: &ldquoThe Chancellor has confirmed that the Government forecasts a disastrous hit to our economy and living standards in the event of a &lsquono deal&rsquo Brexit.The Committee will expect an updated analysis to be published in good time to inform Parliament&rsquos key decisions on the final deal.&ldquoThe Chancellor has not committed to producing an analysis of the short-term economic fallout of a &lsquono deal&rsquo Brexit.

title: brexit latest news jacob rees mogg chequers plan eu latest
story: Last night the grandson of William Churchill, the Conservative MP Sir Nicholas Soames, criticised Jacob Rees-Mogg for an &ldquoastonishing letter to the Chairman of local parties, in which he urged them not to support the Prime Minister&rsquos Chequers plan.Mr Soames, MP for Mid Sussex, expressed his dismay towards his colleague&rsquos decision on Twitter on Thursday, signalling the Tory&rsquos internal isions on Brexit show no sign of relenting.The 70-year-old tweeted: &ldquoThe problem with @Jacob_Rees_Mogg is that people confuse his undoubted fluency and a moderately well cut suit with wisdom but sadly he&rsquos plain wrong #astonishinglettertoConstituencyPartyChairmenOn Wednesday, Mr Rees-Mogg wrote a letter to local Tory party chairs and his parliamentary colleagues urging them to &ldquochuck Chequers.                'We will NOT compromise on what the people voted for', says Hunt                Jacob Rees-Mogg calls for WTO Brexit over Chequers dealThe backbench MP of North East Somerset insisted that the &ldquoChequers proposals would shackle us to the EU forever.And today furious Brexiteers have attacked the latest intervention by Chancellor Philip Hammond.Mr Hammond revealed fears in a letter where he warned a no-deal would damage the British economy.He said analysis showed a 7.7 percent hit to GDP in the next 15 years.In a scathing response, Mr Rees-Mogg said: As a dog returneth to its vomit, so a fool returneth to its folly.Philip Hammond has been scorned by his colleagues (Image: )The Conservatives are running out of time to negotiate a Brexit deal before Britain&rsquos scheduled departure in March 2019.Yesterday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab, outlined what he described as &ldquopractical and proportionate advice in case the UK crashes out of the EU without a deal.However, ministers say a deal is the most likely outcome but that &ldquoshort-term disruption is possible, if one isn&rsquot ratified soon.See below for Brexit updates1.24pm update: Conservative MP laments Philip Hammond&rsquos Brexit commentsBrexiteer and Conservative MP, John Redwood, has lamented Philip Hammond&rsquos warnings surrounding the UK leaving the European Union without a deal.Speaking on talkRADIO, Mr Redwood said: &ldquoSomebody has certainly turned this into a big row.&ldquoThe Chancellor may not have intended to be as firm as it has come across in the Remain seeking press and media but clearly what people have done is taken out of his ill-judged letter.&ldquoThe idea that over 15 years the models that some civil servants have developed there could be a loss of GDP relative to what was otherwise achieved.&ldquoOf course, the phrase 'there are serious fiscal consequences' is going to be taken out of Hammond's letter and blown up.&ldquoIt's completely wrong. It's utter twaddle.12.30pm update: Brexit could save Britons &ldquomany billions of poundsBrexiteer barrister Martin Howe has claimed that a no deal Brexit would allow Britons to save &ldquomany billions of pounds as Britain would no longer be subject to tariffs on imports imposed by the European Union.Mr Howe suggested Britain could benefit from a no deal Brexit, as it would allow the country to &ldquopursue a sensible tariff policy on WTO rules.Mr Howe said that crashing out of the bloc would save Britons &ldquobillions of pounds.He said: The effect is pretty vast because if we pursue a sensible tariff policy we would be able to cut the costs of our imports on goods across the board by a very considerable level.You&rsquore looking at savings in the many billions of pounds a year for British consumers.11.30am update: October &lsquono longer&rsquo deadline for Brexit agreementOctober is no longer the deadline for a Brexit agreement with the EU, the Cabinet Office minister David Lidington has said.&nbspIn an interview on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, Mr Lidington said the EU would have no problem scheduling an emergency meeting to finalise the deal and that having November as the deadline would be &ldquomanageable.Both the EU and UK have so far been working on the assumption that the deal is supposed to be agreed at the European council meeting, which starts on October 18th.&nbsp10.54am update: Philip Hammond slapped downChancellor Phillip Hammond has been condemned by his colleagues for his alleged Brexit scaremongering.The comments were made after Mr Hammond reiterated a warning that a no deal Brexit could damage the UK economy.Conservative MP, Marcus Fysh, accused the Chancellor of embarking on &ldquoanother instalment of dodgy project fear, while a Number 10 source said Britain will ultimately suceed, no matter what our particular relationship with the EU.John McDonnell said Labour will oppose a disorderly Brexit (Image: )10.46am update: Labour considering all optionsLabour is not taking the option of a second EU referendum off the table, Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell has said.Mr McDonnell said Labour will oppose a disorderly Brexit and described the government&rsquos 24 technical notes, which were published yesterday as part of the preparations for a possible no deal scenario, as &ldquoextremely worrying.&nbspThe comments come after Labour&rsquos Shadow Brexit Secretary, Keir Starmer, said his party&rsquos policy would be to keep all &ldquooptions on the table too.&nbsp10.00am update:&nbspAustria makes avoiding hard Brexit main priority&nbspAustria has made avoiding a hard Brexit its top priority during its presidency of the European Union.Sebastian Kurz, the Austrian Chancellor, offered to assist the European Commission&rsquos Chief Brexit Negotiator, Michel Barnier, in negotiating a deal before March 2019.Talks are currently at an impasse over several key issues including a potential hard border in Ireland.Thousands take to the streets of London for Brexit march.                    PA1 of 21People took to the streets of London to march for a second EU referendum9.20am update: Conservative peer highlights three reasons why Brexit deal is likelyA Conservative Peer has highlighted three reasons why the European Union is &ldquolikely to agree a Brexit deal with the UK, as fears of a no-deal continue to increase.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, Lord Price, claimed there were three reasons from the &ldquoEuropean side that made a deal more &ldquolikely.He said: &ldquoThe first is the volume of exports from the EU to the UK and I know that European trade ministers are particularly concerned about agriculture and the &pound10bn surplus of agricultural goods coming from the EU into the UK.&ldquoThere is also a very strong feeling that if there is not a collaborative deal the UK will take a course that will turn it into a &lsquoSingapore off the coast of Europe&rsquo. So we will become more open, more competitive. We will, for instance, reduce cooperation tax, we will bring more businesses in. If therefore the EU pushes us away, we will become an extraordinarily strong competitor in a different sense.&ldquoLastly, there is a genuine fear that if they push us too hard then we will fall into the arms of America.&ldquoSome people talk about us being the 51st state of America but clearly there could be a stronger relationship with America.Philip Hammond said borrowing could be around &pound80bn higher a year after Brexit (Image: )8.45am update: Philip Hammond issues no deal Brexit warning&nbspChancellor Philip Hammond has warned that a no deal Brexit would have &ldquolarge fiscal consequences for the UK economy.Mr Hammond reiterated a previous government analysis, that claimed borrowing could be around &pound80bn a year higher by 2023-34 if the UK crashes out of the bloc in March 2019.The Chancellor made the comments in a letter to Conservative MP and Chair of the Treasury Select Committee, Nicky Morgan.

story: Prince George will join the rest of Year One and improve his skills he acquired in Reception, including handwriting, better speech and basic Maths skills.The five-year-old will have a 35-minute ballet lesson each week and pupils will also have swimming lessons for the first time.The school&rsquos website says that ballet &ldquodevelops students' physical skills, stamina, creativity, expression and musicality, using a range of sounds and musical styles.&ldquoThis strong foundation prepares students for a successful transition to Ballet and other dance genres.                Meghan Markle: How she won Princess Charlotte and Prince George over                Friend of Prince George could play KEY role in next royal wedding The prince&rsquos 35-minute French class will entail greeting and songs and the pupils will be encouraged to speak the language out loud.If the heir to the throne wishes, he can join the school choir, learn a musical instrument or even do a drama class.Of course if the Prince does want to pursue drama, he will be able to ask his aunt, the former Suits actress Meghan Markle for advice.On the school&rsquos website, head of lower school Helen Haslem said: &ldquoChildren in Year One become increasingly independent and confident and begin to relish the opportunity to tackle new challenges presented to them across the broad curriculum.Prince George will go back to school in a few weeks and will be in Year One  (Image: )The Duke of Cambridge dropped off his son last year when he started school  (Image: Reuters )Prince George&rsquos religion classes will include an introduction to the Bible and the New Testament and he will also visit a church and learn about Judaism.The step from Reception to Year One will mean that Prince George can expect more homework, which will be in the form of ten minutes reading each night and a spelling rule each week.One year ago, the young prince was greeted by the head of the lower school Ms Haslem when he arrived at the school gates with his adoring father, the Duke of Cambridge.Helen Haslem greeted Prince George on his first day  (Image: REUETRS )Prince George's first day at St. Thomas school in Battersea. title: Brexit news update David Davis EU UK Brexit no deal Chequers
story: Speaking on TalkRadio, Mr Davis claimed despite Theresa May's proposal would not fully deliver the Brexit Britons voted for in the June&nbsp2016 referendum, any outcome would still be better than remaining in the Brussels bloc.The former Brexit Secretary, who quit in protest to the Prime Minister's Chequers proposal, argued UK trade will undoubtedly flourish outside the EU.He said: &ldquoThe majority of our trade is going to the rest of the world, we will reinforce those things.&ldquoI think under any circumstance we&rsquore going to be better off outside the union.                British businessman DISMISSES fears of no deal Brexit with KEY point                Brexit news: 'Disruption REGARDLESS' &ndash EU responds to UK no-deal plans&ldquoBut I do still think that the proposal from Chequers, which I argued against very firmly on the day, will not meet the undertakings we got from people.&ldquoAnd that&rsquos the fundamental problem.Brexit Secretary&nbspDominic Raab&nbspinsisted on Thursday that an agreement is within our sights and that about 80 percent of the issues standing in the way of a withdrawal deal had been resolved.Mr Raab gave a speech in London to present a series of 25 technical notices outlining contingency plans for business and industries to prepare for an abrupt exit from the EU.Brexit news: David Davis claims any Brexit outcome will be better than staying in the EU (Image: )He said: We have made clear that if negotiations don't achieve the optimum outcome we will continue to be a responsible European neighbour and partner.&nbspWe have a duty, as a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality. These technical notices, and the ones that will follow, are a sensible, measured, and proportionate approach to minimising the impact of no deal on British firms, citizens, charities and public bodies.British businesses will have to declare all imports from the continent and pay customs duties, also treating EU nations as third countries after a no deal Brexit, according to one of the Brexit papers.The paper warned firms will have to apply the same customs procedures as they do when importing goods from a country outside the EU.It said: This means that for goods entering the UK from the EU an import declaration will be required. Customs checks may be carried out and any customs duties must be paid.Brussels&rsquo chief negotiator Michel Barnier voiced his concerns of an EU &ldquoblame game emerging in British no-deal debates.After meeting with Mr Raab on Tuesday, the Frenchman said: &ldquoTo be very frank with you, I do see this blame game starting against the European Union in the case of no deal.&ldquoBut the European Union is not going to be impressed by that kind of blame game, everyone should understand that.

title: Brexit news Jacob Rees Mogg downing street Westminster new house conservative Ashcroft
story: The huge townhouse, which is the former abode of Leave-backing Lord Ashcroft, is 390 yards away from Parliament - closer than number 10 Downing Street - and will be home to Mr Rees-Mogg, his wife Helena and their six children.Mr Rees-Mogg will use the residence to plot his latest Commons revolt as he sets out his own vision for a bright future outside of the European Union.A faction of Brexiteer rebels, spearheaded by the eccentric MP, is working to create an &ldquoalternative view to the Government&rsquos Chequers plan, which was rubbished both by Westminster and the EU.Mr Rees-Mogg, who is considered to be on the right of the Tory party, heads the pro-Brexit European Research Group, which has the backing of about 60 backbench MPs.                &lsquoMay will SHACKLE us to EU forever&rsquo - Rees-Mogg says &lsquoCHUCK CHEQUERS'The 'Brexiteer brigade' is devising a scheme to oust Theresa May and commandeer control of Brexit by laying out a positive Brexit blueprint.And Mr Rees-Mogg will use his new Westminster home as a political power base as he spearheads the battle for a clean break with Brussels.The lavish five-storey 18th Century building in Cowley Street is just 390 yards from the Commons - even closer than Downing Street.It is where Winston Churchill went to plot against Neville Chamberlain in 1940 and in the 1970s, former Labour Prime Minister Sir Harold Wilson claimed that his townhouse at 5 Lord North Street had been bugged by MI5.The huge townhouse is the former abode of Leave-backing Lord Ashcroft (Image: )Mr Rees-Mogg, his wife Helena and their six children will move into the property (Image: )Rumours abound that Mr Rees-Mogg fancies himself in number 10  (Image: )Removal men were seen at the mansion, carrying in an array of furniture and fittings - including patriotic items such as an umbrella stand sporting a Union Flag.Beds, a dishwasher, and a cardboard box marked &ldquohanging garment carrier were also moved into the new home.Other opulent items included a vintage-looking pram, some ornate chairs and an assortment of shrubs.Mr Rees-Mogg, who is tipped as a hot favourite to be the next Prime Minister, is rumoured to have a net worth of at least &pound100million.                'EU is a failing economic model' UK will thrive outside the EU with                Could Brexit technical warning SCARE public into accepting Chequers deBookies regularly place the hardline Brexiteer as within the top three most likely to replace Mrs May.Downplaying leadership speculation, Mr Rees-Mogg said: I bought it because I have six children.My Mayfair house has three bedrooms for nine people so reception rooms now have children in them.From his new home, the MP for North East Somerset will have an even shorter walk to work than the Prime Minister herself.His moving to the new property, just a stone&rsquos throw away from Westminster, will no doubt fuel rumours about his leadership ambitions.The Somerset MP paid &pound5.625million for the property earlier this year, partly funded by a mortgage from the Queen's bank, Coutts &amp Co.

title: Brexit news Jacob Rees Mogg WTO no deal Theresa May Chequers deal
story: When asked by on Newsnight which of the two he would prefer, Mr Rees-Mogg replied: &ldquoOh WTO terms are much better because we&rsquove actually left the European Union and can flourish in that way.He explained: &ldquoThe problem with chequers is that it means not leaving the European Union and remaining subject to the European Union&rsquos rulebook, and therefore de facto to the European Court of Justice.&ldquoLeaving on WTO terms is not as absurd as the Chancellor of the Exchequer thinks it may be.However he added his preferred Brexit agreement with the EU would be a &ldquoCanada style free trade deal.                Could Brexit technical warning SCARE public into accepting Chequers de                Brexit HQ? Rees-Mogg moves into HUGE mansion Asked whether such a deal would make it through our europhile Parliament Mr Rees-Mogg replied: &ldquoWell it would be very likely to because it would depend on what the alternative was.&ldquoIf the alternative was leaving without any deal other than WTO terms then a free trade deal would be very attractive to many members of parliament, much more so than Chequers.&ldquoChequers probably would have a harder time getting through Parliament than a Canada style free trade deal.Mr Rees-Mogg was also asked about the claim by the Confederation of British Industry (CBI_ that leaving on WTO terms would damage the economy.&ldquoLeaving on WTO terms is not as absurd as the Chancellor of the Exchequer thinks it may be (Image: )&ldquoThe problem with chequers is that it means not leaving the European Union (Image: )In response he went on the attack saying: &ldquoThe CBI&rsquos record is even worse than the Treasury&rsquos.&ldquoThe CBI thought we should join the ERM, it thought we should join the Euro.He also noted that the CBI had predicted the UK economy would shrink by 3.6 percent to 6 percent if there was a Brexit vote, and that unemployment would increase by between 500,000 and 800,000.Neither of these have taken place.Neither of these have taken place.Also appearing on Newsnight, Mike Thompson, CEO of The Association of the British Pharmaceutical Industry warned Brexit is &ldquothe biggest logistical challenge that we&rsquove faced in peacetime.However, he claimed it&rsquos the EU which really needs to step up its preparations, saying it hasn&rsquot done as much as the UK.&ldquoThe CBI thought we should join the ERM, it thought we should join the Euro (Image: BBC NEWSNIGHT)He claimed: &ldquoActually the UK&rsquos ahead, British patients are being more protected by the UK Government than the other member states are doing for their patients.&ldquoThis is a call out to other member states to say you need to get planning too.

title: Brexit news UK EU Theresa May Dominic Raab European Union no deal BBC
story: Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab outlined on Thursday how Britain is preparing for a no-deal scenario with the EU.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, a Conservative peer and former minister for trade claimed there were three reasons from the &ldquoEuropean side that made a deal more &ldquolikely.The former Managing Director of Waitrose, and Deputy Chairman of the John Lewis Partnership also claimed that he thought Mr Raab&rsquos intervention on Thursday was helpful.He said: &ldquoI would start by saying I think pragmatically there will be a deal and I think the papers yesterday helped towards that.                BREXIT BETRAYAL: Chancellor claims No Deal Brexit would harm economy                'We will NOT compromise on what the people voted for', says Hunt&ldquoWhat they do is they bring into reality what it will look like if we are unable to achieve a deal so for the first time the rhetoric and the reality collide.&ldquoWhat it demonstrates is that it will be very complicated for the UK and costly if we are unable to do that.&ldquoBut I also think there are a number things from the European side that make doing a deal more likely.Lord Price then outlined the three reasons from the European side why he thought a deal was more likely.He said: &ldquoThe first is the volume of exports from the EU to the UK and I know that European trade ministers are particularly concerned about agriculture and the &pound10billion surplus of agricultural goods coming from the EU into the UK.&ldquoThere is also a very strong feeling that if there is not a collaborative deal the UK will take a course that will turn it into a &lsquoSingapore off the coast of Europe&rsquo. So we will become more open, more competitive. We will, for instance,&nbspreduce cooperation tax, we will bring more businesses in. If therefore the EU pushes us away, we will become an extraordinarily strong competitor in a different sense.&ldquoLastly, there is a genuine fear that if they push us too hard then we will fall into the arms of America.&ldquoSome people talk about us being the 51st state of America but clearly there could be a stronger relationship with America.Lord Price added that for &ldquoall of those reasons he believed there would be a Brexit agreement which was &ldquoin the interests of both sides.Brexit news: Lord Price outlined three reasons why there would be a Brexit deal (Image: &bullBBC)But the peer also claimed negotiations could &ldquogo to the wire as he called for a &ldquopragmatic approach.During a speech on Thursday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab outlined how the UK is preparing to leave the European Union without a deal.During his speech, he said: &ldquoNaturally we have to got to consider the alternative possibility, that the EU does not match our ambition and pragmatism, and we do not reach a deal.&ldquoLet me be clear about this. This is not what we want. And it&rsquos not what we expect. But, we must be ready.&ldquoWe have a duty, as a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality.The Brexit Secretary explained during his speech that there is already planning talks between the Bank of England and the European Central Bank for a no-deal scenario and called for talks to begin on data protection and between port authorities.Under current plans, the reports will be published in batches, starting on Thursday and running through September.

title: Brexit news UK EU Labour Party second referendum European Union Dominic Raab BBC
story: Labour Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said all options are on the table should Theresa May fail to have her Brexit deal passed in Parliament.John McDonnell has sided with the shadow Brexit secretary adding that Labour were &ldquonot taking any options off the table when the deal returns to Parliament.Speaking on BBC Radio 4&rsquos Today programme, presenter Kamal Ahmed said: &ldquoCould you just clear up something for us. Your view of the possibility of a second referendum or what is called a People&rsquos Vote?&ldquoWe have had Barry Gardiner your shadow international trade secretary saying that having such a second vote would lead to civil disobedience and was undemocratic.                Tory peer outlines THREE reasons why EU will give UK a Brexit deal                BREXIT LIVE: Tories at WAR as Soames condemns Jacob Rees-Mogg&ldquoYou have had the shadow Brexit secretary Sir Keir Starmer suggesting that it should be on the table. What is the official policy of the Labour Party on this second vote issue.Mr McDonnell ruled out a second referendum before claiming Labour were not &ldquotaking options off the table when the Government returns to Parliament with the Brexit agreement.He said: &ldquoFirst of all, it is not Labour Party policy to have&nbspanother&nbspreferendum, that&rsquos it, we respect the past referendum.&ldquoBut, we recognise that when the Government comes forward with its proposals, if it does, I&rsquom worried that we might be in a no-deal situation.&ldquoBut, when the Government comes forward with its proposals Parliament will decide the next step.&ldquoWe are not taking any options off the table when that debate happens.&ldquoMy own view is actually I have said consistently, the Labour Party is not opposed to any form of democratic engagement, I would prefer a general election.&ldquoBut Barry was right that we have to be extremely careful. A number of us are worried about the rise of the far-right in this country and elsewhere and what we mustn&rsquot do is open up any opportunities of the far-right exploiting this issue.&ldquoWe have already seen violence on our streets from the far-right when we saw the Tommy Robinson demonstrations on the police and others so Barry is right to caution how we handle this issue because what we want to do, and I think only the Labour Party can do this is bring the country back together again around a compromise for the way forward.Brexit news: McDonnell didn't rule out another Brexit vote when the final deal returns to Parliament (Image: &bullSKYNEWS)On Thursday the shadow Brexit secretary Keir Starmer said all options are on the table should Theresa May fail to have her Brexit deal passed in Parliament.He told the Today programme: &ldquoI focused obviously on the vote in Parliament and the meaningful vote. If that vote is to reject the Article 50 deal, Parliament must decide what happens next.In those circumstances, it seems to me all options remain on the table.He added: &ldquoWe&rsquove not called for a vote on the deal, we&rsquove called for a vote in Parliament on the deal.But I accept the proposition that if this is voted down, Parliament then decides what happens next and in those circumstances keep your options on the table, not off the table.Speaking later on Thursday, Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab outlined how the UK is preparing to leave the European Union without a deal.During his speech, he said: &ldquoNaturally we have to got to consider the alternative possibility, that the EU does not match our ambition and pragmatism, and we do not reach a deal.&ldquoLet me be clear about this. This is not what we want. And it&rsquos not what we expect. But, we must be ready.&ldquoWe have a duty, as a responsible government, to plan for every eventuality.The Brexit Secretary explained during his speech that there is already planning talks between the Bank of England and the European Central Bank for a no-deal scenario and called for talks to begin on data protection and between port authorities.Under current plans, the reports will be published in batches, starting on Thursday and running through September.

title: Brexit news Martin Howe no deal UK EU withdrawal latest WTO rules British imports
story: Martin Howe QC suggested Britain could benefit from a no deal Brexit as it would allow the country to pursue a sensible tariff policy on WTO rules.The Brexiteer barrister claimed breaking off from the European Union without a deal would save Britons billions of pounds because of the immediate end of validity of EU tariff requirements.Speaking to Channel 4 News, Mr Howe said: The effect is pretty vast because if we pursue a sensible tariff policy we would be able to cut the costs of our imports on goods across the board by a very considerable level.You&rsquore looking at savings in the many billions of pounds a year for British consumers.                Austria makes its BIGGEST EU priority avoiding hard BrexitMr Howe explained that studies on the effective costs of a no deal showed Britain would still have to pay around &pound5billion in tariffs to Brussels but insisted it would be significantly less than its current contributions.He continued: The European Union would naturally, in fact, it&rsquos required by WTO rules, to impose the same tariffs on imports from the UK as it does from the rest of the world.Studies have been done on how much that would be and that&rsquos around &pound5billion a year which exporters pay, it&rsquos under half our current net budget contribution.Time is running out and if no deal is struck by the time we leave in March the UK will revert to trading under WTO rules.Brexit news: Martin Howe described the pretty vast effect a no deal would have on UK consumers (Image: CHANNEL 4 NEWS)Under a no deal&nbspscenario, Britain can enter into free trade agreements without the imposition of costly tariffs.David Paton, professor of industrial economics at Nottingham University Business School, said: &ldquoBrexit provides the UK with a historic opportunity but only if we choose to free ourselves from EU protectionism and leave the customs union and single market.By doing so, we can expand our links with the fastest growing economies around the world, decrease prices in the shops and re-design our economic and tax policy in a way which works for the UK rather than having to do as we are told by the European Commission.The Department for Exiting the European Union said: &ldquoWe firmly believe it is in the interests of both the EU and the UK to strike a deal. That remains the goal on both sides and we are confident that this will be achieved.&ldquoBut it is the job of a responsible Government to prepare for all scenarios, including the unlikely event that we reach March 2019 without agreeing on a deal.

story: Speaking to BBC Breakfast this morning, Andrew Bridgen, MP for North West Leicestershire blasted Liberal Democrat MP Tom Brake, saying that &ldquopeople like the MP for Carshalton and Wallington &ldquohave never accepted the result of the referendum.The spat came as the pair discussed the progress of Brexit&nbspnegotiations and Conservative Party isions over the UK's departure from the European Union.Liberal Democrat MP Mr Brake claimed that there is now&nbspa significant support for a second referendum and that both a &ldquono deal scenario and the Chequers agreement would be a &ldquodisaster for the UK.Mr Brake said: &ldquoWhat we&rsquove had since the referendum vote is a number of polls pointing towards people having shifted towards supporting Remain. They&rsquore undermining our government&rsquos position and our countries position as we negotiate, democratically, to leave the European Union.Earlier this week, Liberal Democrat leader Vince Cable claimed at an anti-Brexit Bristol rally that Parliament could legislate for a fresh referendum on the UK&rsquos membership of the EU within weeks.The rally, organised by the People&rsquos Vote campaign group who are calling for a public vote on the final Brexit deal, saw hundreds gather at Bristol's Colston Hall for the first in a programme of activism planned across the UK.At the rally, Remainer Sir Vince dismissed concerns from those he labelled as Brexiteer &ldquofanatics that there would be no time to legislate for a second public vote.He said: &ldquoThey are wrong, if not deliberately misleading.&ldquoIf parliament could pass laws to nationalise banks during the financial crash in a matter of days, then we can secure the legislation to allow people their right to a final say within weeks.But contrary to Sir Vince&rsquos comments, the Electoral Commission advised legislation should be cleared at least six months before polling day.On Friday, Labour Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer said all options are on the table should Theresa May fail to have her Brexit deal passed in Parliament, including a second referendum.John McDonnell has also sided with the shadow Brexit secretary adding that Labour was &ldquonot taking any options off the table when the deal returns to Parliament.

title: UK weather forecast latest Met Office august 2018 September forecast long range weather
story: UK weather forecast latest: Britain temperatures to heat up (Image: Netweather)Thermometers will plunge more than 10C over the next few days after reaching the high 20Cs during the week.Forecasts for sunshine, showers and below-average temperatures on Monday have dashed hopes for a bank holiday scorcher.However golden rays will make a comeback during the start of September giving the nation a lift just as schools go back.Britain could be facing another lengthy blast of sweltering weather with largely dry conditions raising fears of an autumn drought.Southern England will hang on to the higher temperatures tomorrow while the mercury starts to nosee across the rest of the country.All of the UK will be cooler than normal for the time of year by the end of the week as cold air sweeps in from Iceland.The mercury will reach 25C (77F) in south-eastern England on Thursday before dropping to around 18C (64F) at the weekend.                BBC Weather Forecast: temperatures DROP after two day MINI-HEATWAVE                August Bank Holiday travel: Wet weather WARNING for 14 MILLION driversScotland and northern Britain will be wrapping up for overnight lows of freezing on Saturday night, the Met Office said.Meteorologist Becky Mitchell said: &ldquoThrough the end of this week we will be drawing in much cooler air from around Iceland which will be Arctic in origin.&ldquoIt will become chilly on Saturday night and we expect grass frosts and air frosts across the countryside in parts of the UK, we could see the first air frost since before summer.&ldquoOvernight temperatures could dip to freezing on Saturday night and it will be a chilly start on Sunday for many.While not a complete washout a cooler than average late August bank holiday looms with most of the country likely to see a few spots of rain, she said.Showers will work their way across Britain over the next few days although it will feel warm where the sunshine manages to break through, she added.UK weather: Warming up next weekend (Image: Netweather)She said: &ldquoThere is a chance of rain over the weekend and into the bank holiday, and as these showers move southwards it will feel much fresher.&ldquoOn Monday eastern Britain will be more at risk of seeing rain while it is expected to be drier in the west, however it will be much cooler than average for the time of year.&ldquoWe are going to see quite a dramatic dip in temperatures.A u-turn in the weather after the weekend will put temperatures back on an upward climb through next week.Long-range outlooks suggest warm and dry weather will dominate the first month of the meteorological autumn.Miss Mitchell added: &ldquoAs we go through the start of next week temperatures will be on the rise returning back to normal and perhaps becoming quite warm in the south.&ldquoInto September and it looks like it will become rather warm, again particularly in the south with a lot of dry sunny weather on the cards.UK weather forecast: Arctic air arriving this weekend (Image: Netweather)&ldquoWe could get some warmer temperatures coming in again, however it is still quite far away so there is some uncertainty.&ldquoIt looks like we will also see a much more settled pattern due to high pressure taking charge.Sweltering conditions which kept the nation in a blazing furnace through much of summer could be about to make a comeback, according to some independent experts.Exacta Weather forecaster James Madden said there is a chance of seeing the mercury push 30C (86F) over the next few weeks.He said: &ldquoThere are now some absolutely epic and consistent heatwave projections coming out for the start of autumn.&ldquoThere is every chance that Britain could be drenched in prolonged periods of sunshine and very high temperatures.&ldquoIt is now with high confidence that we can say that the warmth from the summer will extend into much of September and the start of Autumn, so an Indian summer is almost as certain.Uk weather forecast: September long range forecast predicting warmer than average (Image: Netweather)&ldquoWe would not be surprised to see temperatures climbing well into the 30's at times during September.Latest Met Office forgers show summer 2018 should turn out to be one of the warmest on record.June was the third warmest on record while July came second in records going back to 1910, according to government weather analysts.With a mean temperature so far of 16.1C (60.98F) this summer is on par with the record-breaking scorcher of 2006.Even if the rest of August turns out to be cooler than current forecasts suggest, summer 2018 will still finish in the top five, according to the Met Office.Dr Mark McCarthy, head of the Met Office National Climate Information Centre, said: &ldquoThe mean temperature measure gives a fuller picture of what the UK climate is doing.&ldquoOn this measure it&rsquos clear that the meteorological summer of 2018 is exceptional, simply for the consistent levels of warmth seen throughout the period so far.The average maximum temperature so far this summer for the UK is 21.1C (69.98F) with an average mean of 16.1C (60.98F).The UK has received just half the normal rainfall over the past three months with around 110 per cent of the usual levels of sunshine, according to Met Office figures.UK weather charts show temperatures stubbornly anchoring higher than normal through September and beyond in some parts.John Hammond, meteorologist with Weathertrending, warned big changes will bring an early taste of across the UK in time for the bank holiday.He said: &ldquoWe are going to go from late summer to, dare I say it, early autumn, there are some big changes on the way. story: The image, taken by an Expedition 56 crew member aboard the International Space Station on Wednesday, shows the huge hurricane building in force in the Central Pacific Ocean.The latest update from the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) provided at 7am BST reported the eye of Hurricane Lane moving towards the north at 6mph.The eye of Hurricane Lane - the most destructive part of a storm - is forecasted to get dangerously close to parts of the main Hawaiian islands later tonight.Throughout Friday, the tropical storm is expected to continue on its northwards path, before turning west over the course of the weekend. story: Hurricane Lane is powering towards the islands of Oahu and Kauai as major businesses close and residents flee to safety.So far, Hurricane Lane has triggered severe flash flooding for much of Big Island, and mudslides have cascaded over roads.As Hurricane Lane drives towards the furthest islands, government officials have warned to prepare for the worst, and shelters have been readied.Hawaii Civil Defence warns that extreme caution should be exercised if people are intending to travel towards shelter at this time. title: hotel staff confessions
story: The most salacious stories tend to emerge from hotel bedrooms, where sleeping is often the last thing guests have on their minds - and staff often have no choice but to turn a blind eye to kinky sex games, even the grooms who cheat on their wedding nights.At other times, theyre drafted in to deal with violent guests, dead bodies... and worse.Here, four hotel workers reveal all:Maria Smith, 26, is a mum of one. She lives on the Isle of Man and works as a pub manager.She says: I used to work in one of the island’s poshest hotels. We’d get British celebs like David Tennant staying all the time.They were easy to deal with and normally they checked in to chill out.But during the Isle of Man motorbike racing the high flyers would arrive.In the hotel we’d regularly see strippers strutting around offering private dances and other services to the guests.One well-to-do couple checked out looking prim and proper, but when my colleague opened the room to their bedroom it turned out theyd had a crazy sex party.They’d left behind huge dildos and filthy bedding.Dirty weekends are routine. There was one guy who had a suite on permanent reservation and had a carousel of different women coming to stay with him.Guests regularly chat up the staff, and some would think nothing of manhandling us either.One famous older man pinched my bum when I was serving him. As soon as my hands were free I hit him with my tray.Deaths do happen though. One nasty incident involved an elderly guy who was staying for the TT motorbike race.His intestines had exploded and he haemorrhaged out in the room.The stench was awful - you could smell it along the corridor.The room was like a scene from a Quentin Tarrantino film with blood on the carpet, the bed and up the walls.You just have to clean it up as quickly as possible so the room is ready to rent again.Hotel receptionist Anna Thistlethwaite, 31 is a married mum of one who lives in Cambridge.She says: I have worked in the hotel industry for three years as front of house at a 4-star hotel in Hertfordshire.A common occurrence at weddings is for couples to go to their rooms - then when the bride passes out drunk the  groom goes and has sex with someone else.He’ll even go back and check his new wife is still asleep before returning to the woman in the other room. It happens a lot.We catch the blokes out because they always mix up the key cards.We make them wait at reception for as long as possible to reissue them with one for their room.One guest would check in every Friday night, pay for his room in cash and refuse to give any contact details.Forty-five minutes later a woman would literally run across the lobby and head towards his room.It was obvious he was cheating on his wife but we couldn’t work out if she was a prostitute or his mistress.We routinely see businessmen come in with different women during conference weeks.The wife normally joins them at the end none the wiser to what he has been up to.We have to keep a straight face and remember that the customer is always right.Josh Tully, 27, is general manager of La Vue France, boutique hotel &amp wedding venue in southwest France. He says: I used to work for an upscale UK establishment which was the destination for the rich and famous.One A-list Hollywood star flew in to give the bride away at her wedding.It was raining lightly and he refused to walk outside in case he ruined his Louis Vuitton suede loafers so we had to ensure there was a buggy available at all times to take him to and from the church and hotel.Anyone would have thought he was the bride.Another time, a guest who had reserved in advance asked us to ensure we had a £500 bottle of vintage Krug champagne on ice for his arrival.Our supplier let us down on the morning – so we improvised.We presented him with a bottle of the £20 house champagne and he was none the wiser.He thanked us for going to the trouble of getting it in and even explained how you could taste the difference.We kept a straight face and took the compliment.Other famous guests included a boy band who stayed to write songs.One of them had a fish only diet - each meal was fish guts, fish oil and fish blood whizzed up in a blender - It smelled disgusting.Yet we all had to go along with it and tell him how amazing he looked as a result of knocking back the revolting shots.One thing Ive learned is that people always seem to get frisky when they go away for the weekend.Once I walked into the games room only to find a couple having sex under the snooker table.They saw me but made the decision to carry on, so I left them to it.They just nodded at me when they eventually walked out.Maria Andrews, 29, lives in Northolt and is a married mum-of-one.She says: I worked in a 4-star hotel for the last five years. Nothing anyone does surprises me any more. I have delivered room service to a man who opened the door completely naked.I walked in and put the tray of two beers and some nibbles on the table. He wandered towards me. I didnt notice he was starker’s until I asked him to sign the bill.As I stood up his willy came into view. It was enormous - I can only assume he wanted to show it off.His wife was in bathtub next door also naked.Neither of them were drunk but - they were just blatant exhibitionists.Then there was the time a woman came downstairs in the middle of the night completely naked.She said shes got locked out after mistaking her room door for bathroom one.We didn’t believe a word of it. We suspect she got caught with someone she shouldn’t have been with and had to scarper.She had to stand at reception starkers while we ran her identity through the system.She had a great body which was just as well as the entire hotel staff saw the security footage of her streaking along the corridors.People behave badly from the moment they check in. I would never go back to the hotel industry. We were treated like sh*t.One man came in to the hotel to use the wifi. When we asked him to leave, he started threatening one of my colleagues with a glass bottle.I jumped on him and pinned him to the floor. It was just as well the police arrived because he was starting to choke.Guests also always assume if it isn’t nailed down then they can pinch it.After one wedding I clocked a woman trying to walk out with several 3-foot high centrepiece hidden under her coat.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
